articles.headline: Stephen Bannon, a Rookie Campaign Chief Who ‘Loves the Fight’
articles.snippet: Donald J. Trump has shuffled his campaign leadership once again, this time appointing the head of the conservative website Breitbart News.
articles.abstract: Donald J. Trump has shuffled his campaign leadership once again, this time appointing the head of the conservative website Breitbart News.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the American financial system collapsed in the fall of 2008, Stephen K. Bannon began to fantasize about destroying something else: the elite economic and political establishment that he believed had created the crisis.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: The Fed Is Searching for a New Framework. New Minutes Show It Doesn’t Have One Yet.
articles.snippet: Has something fundamental shifted? Amid uncertainty, the Fed affirmed the status quo.
articles.abstract: Has something fundamental shifted? Amid uncertainty, the Fed affirmed the status quo.
articles.lead_paragraph: The quandary facing the Federal Reserve this summer is the same as it was back in the spring, and winter, and last fall: By traditional guideposts like the unemployment rate, it looks as if it is time for the Fed to be raising interest rates. Yet the global economy seems to be locked in a low-growth, low-inflation world in which raising interest rates is at best unnecessary and at worst dangerous.

articles.headline: Hedge Funds Avoided Big Losses Despite ‘Brexit’ Shock
articles.snippet: Britain’s vote to leave the European Union sent many fund managers scrambling, but managers cite a number of factors that help explain how some avoided losses.
articles.abstract: Britain’s vote to leave the European Union sent many fund managers scrambling, but managers cite a number of factors that help explain how some avoided losses.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — In late June, as Britons prepared to go to the polls to vote on the country’s membership in the European Union, about 800 hedge fund managers gathered at the opulent Cavalieri hotel on a hill overlooking Rome for an annual rite.

articles.headline: U.N. Admits Role in Cholera Epidemic in Haiti
articles.snippet: The acknowledgment came after a confidential report told the secretary general that the outbreak, which began in 2010, “would not have broken out but for the actions of the United Nations.”
articles.abstract: The acknowledgment came after a confidential report told the secretary general that the outbreak, which began in 2010, “would not have broken out but for the actions of the United Nations.”
articles.lead_paragraph: For the first time since a cholera epidemic believed to be imported by United Nations peacekeepers began killing thousands of Haitians nearly six years ago, the office of Secretary General Ban Ki-moon has acknowledged that the United Nations played a role in the initial outbreak and that a “significant new set of U.N. actions” will be needed to respond to the crisis.

articles.headline: As Insurers Like Aetna Balk, U.S. Makes New Push to Bolster Health Care Act
articles.snippet: An uneasy truce between the government and insurers appears to be fraying as some of the large companies say they are leaving or sharply scaling back.
articles.abstract: An uneasy truce between the government and insurers appears to be fraying as some of the large companies say they are leaving or sharply scaling back.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Facing high-profile withdrawals from online insurance exchanges and surging premiums, the Obama administration is preparing a major push to enroll new participants into public marketplaces under the Affordable Care Act.
articles.byline: By Robert Pear and Reed Abelson

articles.headline: A Danish Wind Turbine Maker Harnesses Data in a Push to Stay Ahead
articles.snippet: Vestas was in a precarious position in 2012, but it is now a market leader, thanks in large part to its focus on data and mathematics.
articles.abstract: Vestas was in a precarious position in 2012, but it is now a market leader, thanks in large part to its focus on data and mathematics.
articles.lead_paragraph: AARHUS, Denmark — A project to install hundreds of wind turbines in the Fosen peninsula area of Norway at one point was shelved as unfeasible. The strong breezes that whip off the sea can shift and swing unpredictably, while the soaring cliffs and steep drop-offs create turbulence that wears out expensive equipment.

articles.headline: Nigeria Is Freeing Children From Boko Haram, Then Locking Them Up
articles.snippet: Civilians, and even infants, are ending up in military detention centers as Nigeria holds people it suspects of being sympathizers of the Islamist extremist group.
articles.abstract: Civilians, and even infants, are ending up in military detention centers as Nigeria holds people it suspects of being sympathizers of the Islamist extremist group.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria — It had been more than a month, and Dije Ali was still locked in a military prison with her seven children.

articles.headline: Debt. Terror. Politics. To Seattle Millennials, the Future Looks Scary.
articles.snippet: Students at a Seattle coding school for women are somewhat optimistic about tech’s promise, but share a generation’s skepticism that the days ahead will be better.
articles.abstract: Students at a Seattle coding school for women are somewhat optimistic about tech’s promise, but share a generation’s skepticism that the days ahead will be better.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Part of Jillian Boshart’s life plays out in tidy, ordered lines of JavaScript computer code, and part in a flamboyant whirl of corsets and crinoline. She’s a tech student by day, an enthusiastic burlesque artist and producer by night. “Code-mode” and “show-mode,” she calls those different guises.

articles.headline: How Omran Daqneesh, 5, Became a Symbol of Aleppo’s Suffering
articles.snippet: Images of the dazed and injured child have quickly made him an emblem of the harrowing misery of Syria’s five-year-old civil war.
articles.abstract: Images of the dazed and injured child have quickly made him an emblem of the harrowing misery of Syria’s five-year-old civil war.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In the images, he sits alone, a small boy coated with gray dust and encrusted blood. His little feet barely extend beyond his seat. He stares, bewildered, shocked and, above all, weary, as if channeling the mood of Syria.
